This clinical vignette describes a patient with schizophrenia who developed gynecomastia due to hyperprolactinemia secondary to risperidone use. This side effect occurs since the atypical antipsychotics block dopamine receptors in the tuberoinfundibular pathway. Amongst the atypical antipsychotics, risperidone is most likely to cause hyperprolactinemia.

The tuberoinfundibular pathway refers to a population of dopamine neurons in the arcuate nucleus (also known as the "infundibular nucleus") in the tuberal region of the hypothalamus that projects to the pituitary median eminence (the "infundibular region"). It is one of the four major dopamine pathways in the brain. Dopamine released at this site regulates prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary gland.

Blockade of dopamine receptors leads to an increase in prolactin, which inhibits the release of GnRH, LH, and FSH. Patients will subsequently develop hypogonadism. Women may present with hirsutism, acne, oligomenorrhea, or amenorrhea. Men can develop gynecomastia. Both men and women can experience infertility, sexual dysfunction, galactorrhea, and decreased bone mineral density.

Ideally, if a patient develops hyperprolactinemia, the atypical antipsychotic should be discontinued. However, if this is not possible, then either 1) the dose may be decreased, 2) the patient can be switched to an alternative atypical antipsychotic, or 3) a full or partial dopamine agonist may be added to the regimen.  

Option Analysis

✅ Increased prolactin levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased GnRH levels:
Incorrect: This patient has gynecomastia, likely secondary to risperidone use. Risperidone increases prolactin release, which in turn suppresses GnRH secretion.  
❌ Decreased aromatase activity:
Incorrect: Aromatase is an enzyme that facilitates the peripheral conversion of testosterone to estrogen. The activity of this enzyme is not affected by risperidone or the other medications this patient is taking.  
❌ Normal LH and FSH levels:
Incorrect: This patient has gynecomastia, likely secondary to risperidone use. Risperidone increases prolactin release. Given that prolactin suppresses GnRH release, the levels of LH and FSH are decreased in patients with hyperprolactinemia. These changes contribute to hypogonadism in both men and women.  
❌ Normal testosterone levels:
Incorrect: This patient has gynecomastia, likely secondary to risperidone use. Risperidone increases prolactin release. Given that prolactin suppresses GnRH, the levels of LH and FSH are decreased, and thus, testosterone levels are also reduced.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the clinic with two days of agitation, fever and rigidity. He was started three days ago on isocarboxazid for refractory depression. Past medical history is significant for generalized anxiety disorder and major depressive disorder. Current medications include buspirone and isocarboxazid. He also takes over-the-counter St. John’s wort and an herbal supplement mixture. Temperature is 38.6 ºC (101.5 ºF), heart rate is 120 bpm, respiratory rate is 16 bpm, blood pressure is 162/88 mmHg. He appears diaphoretic and has a dry mouth. Lungs are clear to auscultation and there are no cardiac murmurs. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. Bilateral biceps and quadriceps reflexes are 3+ bilaterally. Which of the following physiologic changes is responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from serotonin syndrome, which can occur in patients taking multiple agents that promote increased levels of serotonin, such as linezolid, monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOI), and selective norepinephrine and serotonin reuptake inhibitors.  Serotonin syndrome generally occurs shortly (hours to days) after starting a new serotonergic agent. Patients classically present with agitation, hyperthermia, and hyperreflexia. Serotonin syndrome is often confused with neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), which is caused by extensive blockade of dopamine systems via anti-dopaminergic agents. NMS occurs more gradually (days to weeks) and classically presents with hyporeflexia and severe rigidity. Treatment revolves around stopping the offending agent and providing supportive care.  

Multiple medications and herbal supplements have been implicated in causing serotonin syndrome in patients taking MAOI. St. John’s wort is the most common example of a popular herbal supplement that can interfere with MAOI therapy due to its innate MAOI activity. Patients on MAOI need to be educated extensively on dietary habits (e.g., avoiding tyramine-rich foods) and questioned regarding herbal or supplement use.  

Option Analysis

❌ Anti-dopaminergic effects:
Incorrect: Antidopaminergics can lead to neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), which mimics serotonin syndrome. This patient is not taking any anti-dopaminergic agents.
✅ Decreased breakdown of serotonin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Elevated blood pressure:
Incorrect: While monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOI) can cause hypertensive crises, this patient’s blood pressure is elevated due to serotonin syndrome. Technically, his blood pressure does not meet the criteria for a hypertensive crisis (systolic BP >180 and/or diastolic BP >120).
❌ Increased levels of tyramine:
Incorrect: While MAOI (especially non-selective MAOI such as isocarboxazid) can increase levels of tyramine, which can lead to a hypertensive crisis via increased catecholamines.
❌ Increased uptake of norepinephrine:
Incorrect: Selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, such as venlafaxine, reduce (re)uptake of norepinephrine, increasing levels of this neurotransmitter. Increased uptake would cause fewer catecholamine-related effects.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he was found wandering in the park shouting and laughing to himself. The patient has been hearing the voices of his deceased mother and a world-famous singer. The patient has been hospitalized twice in the past, during which his symptoms improved after receiving haloperidol. The patient stopped the medication after discharge due to its side effects. After the patient's condition improves, he is discharged with a prescription for chlorpromazine, for which possible side effects are discussed. When compared to haloperidol, chlorpromazine is more likely to cause which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Typical antipsychotics are classified according to their potency. Low-potency antipsychotics (e.g., chlorpromazine) require higher doses to achieve the same effect as high-potency ones (e.g., haloperidol). Moreover, the two classes of medications have varying side effect profiles.

Low potency antipsychotics have stronger sedating (due to histamine H1 receptor blockade), anticholinergic (dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention), and α1-receptor blockade (orthostatic hypotension) side effects.

In contrast, high-potency antipsychotics have a higher risk of causing neuroleptic malignant syndrome and extrapyramidal symptoms. Extrapyramidal symptoms include acute dystonia (involuntary muscle spasm), akathisia (inability to remain still), pseudo-parkinsonism (tremors, rigidity, bradykinesia), and tardive dyskinesia (repeated lip-smacking, choreiform movements of the extremities).  

Option Analysis

❌ Involuntary neck muscle spasm:
Incorrect: Chlorpromazine is a low-potency antipsychotic. In contrast, high-potency antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol) have a higher risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms such as dystonia.  
❌ Inability to sit still:
Incorrect: Chlorpromazine is a low-potency antipsychotic. In contrast, high-potency antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol) have a higher risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms such as akathisia.  
✅ Sedation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bradykinesia:
Incorrect: High-potency antipsychotics have a higher risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms such as pseudo-parkinsonism, which manifests with bradykinesia, tremors, and rigidity. In contrast, chlorpromazine is a low-potency antipsychotic.  
❌ Repeated lip smacking:
Incorrect: High-potency antipsychotics have a higher risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms such as tardive dyskinesia, which manifests with involuntary repetitive such as lip smacking and writhing of the extremities. In contrast, chlorpromazine is a low-potency antipsychotic.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of lack of sexual desire and difficulty achieving an erection for the past month. Before developing his symptoms, he had an active and satisfactory sexual relationship with his partner. He has no history of cardiac disease, unexpected weight loss, visual changes, or neuropathy symptoms. He reports a significant improvement in his mood and fatigue after initiating pharmacologic therapy for major depressive disorder six weeks ago. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and paroxetine. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in the patient’s father. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a normal body hair distribution, no gynecomastia, equal peripheral pulses bilaterally, an intact bulbocavernosus reflex, and normal testicular size. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's sexual dysfunction? 

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Hemoglobin A1c     5.9 %    
 Creatinine     0.8 mg/dL    
 Total testosterone      455 ng/dL    
 Prolactin     10 ng/mL    
 HDL     45 mg/dL    
 LDL     65 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient’s onset of erectile dysfunction (ED) and loss of libido following the initiation of a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), in the absence of vascular, neurologic, hormonal, and psychogenic abnormality, make medication the most likely cause of ED.

SSRIs (e.g., fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, sertraline, paroxetine, and citalopram) allosterically inhibit the serotonin transporter (SERT) by binding at a site other than that of serotonin and increases its levels in the synaptic cleft. SSRIs are indicated for treating a major depressive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, OCD, and generalized anxiety disorder. SSRIs are considered one of the safest antidepressant medications due to their favorable side effect profile, but significant side effects can occur.

Sexual dysfunction including decreased libido, orgasmic difficulties or anorgasmia, penile anesthesia, and erectile dysfunction (impotence) are common adverse effects of SSRIs in males and females. SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction can be managed by switching to a non-SSRI antidepressant, such as bupropion or mirtazapine, which carry fewer sexual side effects. Other side effects of SSRIs include anxiety, insomnia, GI distress, and syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormones (SIADH). Additional side effects include suicidal ideation, especially in individuals under 25, and serotonin syndrome.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Medication side effect :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Vascular disease :
Incorrect: This patient’s normal vascular examination (e.g., absence of bruit and normal pulses) and well-controlled diabetes mellitus make a vascular abnormality an unlikely cause of erectile dysfunction in this patient. 
❌ Psychogenic :
Incorrect: Psychogenic erectile dysfunction typically presents with a sudden onset and is situational (e.g., with a specific partner and normal erection during masturbation). A psychological stressor usually precedes the onset of psychogenic ED. The onset of ED with decreased libido following the initiation of paroxetine supports the diagnosis of medication-induced ED. 
❌ Neurologic :
Incorrect: This patient’s normal neurologic examination (e.g., normal sensation, motor function, and intact bulbocavernosus reflex) makes this an unlikely cause of ED in this patient. 
❌ Hormonal  :
Incorrect: Normal testosterone and prolactin levels in the absence of gynecomastia make a hormonal imbalance an unlikely etiology of this patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents to the psychiatrist for a follow-up appointment following a recent emergency room incident. Five days ago, the patient presented to the emergency department via ambulance in an unconscious state with involuntary convulsions of the extremities. She has no prior history of seizures. The patient has a 2 year history of having major depressive disorder and had previously been on selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). The patient was recently switched to bupropion after repeatedly expressing concerns about weight gain. The patient takes no other medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 87/62 mmHg, and pulse is 58/min. Physical exam reveals lanugo on the arms. Which of the following is a major contraindication to bupropion use that most likely precipitated the patient’s seizure episode?
questions.solution:
The patient develops new-onset seizures while on bupropion therapy. Further evaluation is notable for lanugo (fine hairs), hypotension, and bradycardia. These findings are concerning for anorexia nervosa. Bupropion is contraindicated in patients with eating disorders since the medication increases the risk of developing seizures.    

Bupropion is an inhibitor of norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake, used to help treat depression and assist in smoking cessation. Due to its dual effects on norepinephrine and dopamine, rather than serotonin, bupropion is not associated with sexual dysfunction. However, bupropion lowers the seizure threshold. As a result, the medication is contraindicated in patients who have conditions that predispose them to seizure activity; such as prior stroke, brain tumors, significant central nervous disease, arteriovenous malformations, or eating disorders (as is the case of this patient).    

Option Analysis

✅ Eating disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypernatremia:
Incorrect: Hypernatremia is not a contraindication to bupropion use. Moreover, this patient does not have a history of risk factors, such as dehydration, diuretic use, or diabetes insipidus, that would predispose her to hypernatremia.  
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Diabetes mellitus is not a contraindication to bupropion use. However, oral hypoglycemic agents and insulin should be used with caution since they can predispose patients to hypoglycemic seizures.    
❌ Hypotensive stroke:
Incorrect: Strokes are a predisposing factor to developing seizure activity, as they create injury and scarring within the brain. However, this patient does not have a clinical history of physical examination findings suggestive of a prior stroke.  
❌ Cardiac arrhythmia:
Incorrect: Cardiac conditions such as arrhythmia do not cause seizures and are not a contraindication to bupropion therapy.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider for a routine visit. She has been struggling with her attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), becoming easily distracted and unfocused in her job as an elementary teacher. She has always managed her ADHD with lifestyle modifications, but her symptoms have worsened since started her job. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Cardiovascular and pulmonary exams are unremarkable. The patient is started on a medication used to treat her ADHD. This medication can also be used to treat hypertension and Tourette syndrome. Which of the following best describes the medication’s effects on α<sub>1</sub>, α<sub>2</sub>, β<sub>1</sub>, and β<sub>2</sub> receptor activity?
questions.solution:
This patient was started on clonidine, which can be used to treat hypertension, Tourette syndrome, and ADHD. Clonidine, along with guanabenz and guanfacine, is an α2-adrenergic receptor agonist. These medications stimulate α2-adrenergic receptors on the presynaptic neurons in the central nervous system (CNS), especially those in the medulla. This decreases norepinephrine in the sympathetic neurons, which leads to lower blood pressure. As a result, these medications can be used to treat hypertension.

Likewise, α2-receptor agonists (clonidine in particular) act on α2-adrenergic receptors present in the prefrontal cortex, where they exert the same inhibitory effect on norepinephrine release. Moderating the amount of norepinephrine in this part of the brain helps “tune out” irrelevant stimuli and sharpens focus. As a result, clonidine is helpful in the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and tics in Tourette syndrome.

Another α2-adrenergic receptor agonist is alpha-methyldopa, which is converted to methyl norepinephrine centrally to decrease the adrenergic outflow by α2-adrenergic agonist action from the central nervous system, leading to reduced total peripheral resistance and decreased systemic blood pressure. Therefore, this medication is occasionally used in the treatment of hypertension.

Another commonly used α2-adrenergic receptor agonist is tizanidine, a centrally acting α2-adrenergic receptor agonist. Tizanidine’s alpha-2 receptor-mediated inhibition of inter-neuronal activity underlies its anti-spasmodic activities and is therefore used to treat spasticity caused by multiple sclerosis or spinal cord injuries.

The main side effect of these medications is hypotension. Also, if a patient abruptly stops taking them, severe rebound hypertension may occur. Other side effects include sedation, fatigue, and nausea/gastric upset.
 

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Medications such as prazosin and terazosin are α1-receptor antagonists. They are used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia and post-traumatic stress disorder. However, none of these medications are used to treat ADHD or Tourette syndrome.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Phenoxybenzamine and phentolamine are nonselective alpha-blockers that reduce both α1 and α2 activity. These medications are used preoperatively in the surgical resection of pheochromocytomas and treat hypertensive crises (e.g. cocaine intoxication). However, these medications are not typically used to treat ADHD or Tourette syndrome.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Norepinephrine acts on both α and β receptors. The medication causes vasoconstriction and would increase the patient’s blood pressure. As a result, norepinephrine is instead used to treat severe hypotension, such as sepsis.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Labetalol is a nonselective α- and β-antagonist. Although it is used to treat hypertension, it is not used to treat ADHD or Tourette syndrome.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office because of excessive somnolence, dizziness, fatigue, and dull headaches for the past week. He has also experienced a decreased appetite due to constant feelings of nausea. The patient was diagnosed with a lower urinary tract infection four days ago and was started on a 14-day course of antibiotics. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and chronic insomnia. Current medications include ramelteon, levofloxacin, and lisinopril. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a tired appearing man. Neurological and cardiopulmonary examinations are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with excessive somnolence, dizziness, fatigue, headaches, and nausea after an antibiotic; likely, a fluoroquinolone is added to his drug regimen. These findings are suggestive of a drug-drug interaction. Ramelteon is metabolized primarily through the cytochrome P1A2 (CYP1A2) enzyme. The coadministration of P1A2 inhibitors has increased ramelteon concentrations, resulting in side effects.    

Ramelteon is a highly selective agonist at the melatonin MT1 and MT2 receptors, prominent in the hypothalamic suprachiasmatic nucleus. It is approved to treat transient and chronic insomnia, with no tolerance associated with prolonged use. The most common side effects are somnolence, dizziness, fatigue, and nausea.    

Likewise, tasimelteon is also a selective agonist for MT1 and MT2 receptors. It has been approved in the United States to treat non-24-h sleep-wake syndrome in totally blind patients experiencing circadian rhythm disorder.  

Option Analysis

✅ Drug-drug interaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Drug overdose:
Incorrect: This patient has been taking ramelteon, which is metabolized by the cytochrome P1A2 enzyme. The coadministration of P1A2 inhibitors such as fluoroquinolones has been shown to increase ramelteon concentrations and the risk of ramelteon-related side effects (e.g., somnolence, dizziness, nausea). Incorrect: Drug-drug interaction is more likely to cause this patient’s symptoms.  
❌  Migraine headache:
Incorrect: Migraine headaches are usually unilateral and may be associated with nausea and vomiting. In contrast, this patient presents with excessive somnolence, fatigue, and nausea after starting a urinary tract infection treatment. These findings suggest a drug-drug interaction between ramelteon and the newly prescribed antibiotic.    
❌ Subarachnoid hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Subarachnoid hemorrhage presents acutely, and patients often describe it as the most severe headache they have ever had. This patient presents with excessive somnolence, dizziness, fatigue, and headaches for the past week, suggesting an alternate cause. Moreover, the patient’s neurological examination is within normal limits.  
❌ Vestibular schwannoma:
Incorrect: Vestibular schwannomas are Schwann cell-derived tumors that commonly arise from the vestibular portion of the eighth cranial nerve. Patients typically present with hearing loss and tinnitus and frequently experience unsteadiness while walking. Excessive somnolence, dizziness, fatigue, and headaches suggest an alternate cause.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the office because of irregular sleep for the past 4-months. The patient states, “My job has become more stressful, and I am afraid I will get fired. I feel like sleeping and often fall asleep while talking to a customer.” The patient goes to bed at 11 PM and wakes up at 9 AM. He occasionally hears a voice while falling asleep and finds himself frozen and unable to move when waking up. He also recalls episodes when he suddenly dropped to the floor after his knees became weak. These episodes typically occur while he is laughing. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is noncontributory. He occasionally drinks alcohol but does not consume tobacco or illicit substances. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. When considering the most likely diagnosis, which of the following medications should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of excessive daytime sleepiness, hallucinations before going to sleep, sleep paralysis, and loss of muscle tone following an emotional trigger (cataplexy) are consistent with narcolepsy. Orexin (hypocretin-1) levels are undetectable in patients with narcolepsy. Therefore, suvorexant, an orexin receptor antagonist, is contraindicated in patients with narcolepsy.    

Suvorexant is approved for the treatment of insomnia. It decreases sleep onset latency and is superior to a placebo in sleep maintenance. The most common adverse reaction is daytime somnolence, and there is a possibility of worsening depression or suicidal ideation. It is contraindicated in narcolepsy, given the medication’s mechanism of action and potential to exacerbate daytime sleepiness. Moreover, the medication should not be administered with potent CYP3A4 inhibitors. It should also be avoided in patients with liver disease (given the medicine is predominantly metabolized by hepatic CYP3A4 enzymes).  

Option Analysis

❌ Modafinil:
Incorrect: Modafinil is the first-line pharmacologic therapy for narcolepsy because it controls sleepiness, is generally well-tolerated, and has low abuse potential. It can be used to manage this patient’s irregular sleep patterns, which are likely due to narcolepsy.  
❌ Methylphenidate:
Incorrect: Methylphenidate is a central nervous system stimulant and a potent wakefulness-promoting drug. It is effective in the management of daytime sleepiness in patients with narcolepsy.  
✅ Suvorexant:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Venlafaxine:
Incorrect: Venlafaxine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) that can be used to manage cataplexy and major depressive disorder.  
❌ Sodium oxybate:
Incorrect: Sodium oxybate, a sodium salt of gamma-hydroxybutyrate (GHB), is a gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) metabolite. Therefore, it is known to reduce cataplexy markedly and is a good medication choice for this patient.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the clinic because of increased thirst and urination for the past week. He has had large volumes of almost clear urine, especially at night. Since symptom onset, the patient has also felt lethargic and confused. Past medical history is significant for bipolar disorder and severe acne. Current medications include lithium, propranolol, aripiprazole, venlafaxine, and isotretinoin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, heart rate is 105/min, and respiratory rate is 10/min. On physical examination, the patient is noted to have decreased skin turgor. Hemoglobin A1c and serum blood glucose are within normal limits. A water deprivation test shows a urinary osmolality less than 300 mOsm/kg after stimulation with ADH. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for the patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has developed nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) likely secondary to lithium use. None of the patient’s other medications are associated with nephrogenic DI.

DI is defined as the passage of large volumes (>3 L/24 hr) of dilute urine (< 300 mOsm/kg). There are 2 main forms of diabetes insipidus, central, and nephrogenic. Central DI is caused by a decrease in antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion, whereas nephrogenic DI results from resistance of the kidneys to ADH. Both can present with polyuria, polydipsia, and nocturia.

Central DI may be distinguished from nephrogenic DI with a water deprivation test, which involves withholding all water intake and measuring urine osmolality. Afterward, ADH is administered to delineate whether the DI is central or nephrogenic. In both central and nephrogenic DI, urine osmolality will initially be less than 300 mOsm/kg after water deprivation. With ADH administration, the osmolality will be > 750 mOsm/kg in central DI. In contrast, there will be no change in nephrogenic DI given the kidneys are unable to respond to ADH.

Treatment for central and nephrogenic DI involves adequate fluid replacement, which can be accomplished through oral intake, and discontinuation of offending agents (e.g. lithium). Intravenous fluids may be used if oral intake is inadequate and the patient is hypernatremic. Although central DI may be treated with desmopressin, nephrogenic DI does not respond to this drug.

Additional side effects associated with lithium therapy are included in the table below.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Lithium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a ꞵ-blocker that may be used as an adjunctive anxiolytic in patients with bipolar disorder. Its main side effects include bradycardia, diarrhea, fatigue, nausea, and hypoglycemia. It is not associated with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.  
❌ Aripiprazole:
Incorrect: Aripiprazole is an atypical antipsychotic that may also be used as a mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder. It acts as a partial agonist of the D2 receptor in the mesolimbic pathway. Its main side effects include vomiting, constipation, fatigue, dizziness, weight gain, and movement disorders. It is not associated with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.  
❌ Venlafaxine:
Incorrect: Venlafaxine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor that may also be used in the treatment of depression associated with bipolar disorder. Its main side effects include anorexia, xerostomia, constipation, dizziness, sweating, and sexual dysfunction. It is not associated with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.  
❌ Isotretinoin:
Incorrect: Isotretinoin (also known by the brand name Accutane) is an oral vitamin A derivative that is used to treat severe nodulocystic acne. Its main side effects include transaminitis, hypertriglyceridemia, and dry skin. However, isotretinoin is not associated with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of bilateral nipple discharge. The patient’s menstrual cycle has been irregular for the past 6-months. She has also experienced mild breast tenderness. The patient is not currently sexually active. Past medical history is significant for atopic dermatitis and recent hospitalization for an episode of psychosis. Family history is significant for breast cancer in the patient’s maternal grandmother. The patient does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Laboratory studies reveal a prolactin level of 80 mg/dL and TSH of 2 mU/L. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bilateral nipple discharge, breast tenderness, and amenorrhea. She has a recent history of hospitalization for psychosis, during which she most likely received antipsychotic medication. In combination, these findings are suggestive of medication-induced hyperprolactinemia, likely secondary to a typical antipsychotic, such as haloperidol.

Typical antipsychotics block D2 receptors in the tuberoinfundibular pathway. Normally, dopamine inhibits prolactin release. When these receptors are blocked, prolactin is released in increased amounts.  Increased prolactin can cause bilateral milky nipple discharge, oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea, decreased libido, and gynecomastia.

In addition, typical antipsychotics can inhibit the nigrostriatal pathway and result in extrapyramidal symptoms. These may manifest as abnormal movements such as tardive dyskinesia, dystonia, akathisia, and pseudoparkinsonism.

Typical antipsychotics also block α1-receptors causing orthostatic hypotension; muscarinic receptors causing anticholinergic side effects including dry mouth, blurred vision, urinary retention, and constipation; and histamine H1 receptors causing sedation. Other side effects include QT interval prolongation and metabolic changes (e.g., weight gain, dyslipidemia, hyperglycemia).
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism can predispose patients to develop hyperprolactinemia. However, this patient’s TSH level is within normal limits, and she does not have other symptoms associated with hypothyroidism (e.g., lethargy, dry skin, cold intolerance).  
❌ Prolactinoma:
Incorrect: Prolactinomas are benign pituitary tumors that can cause visual disturbance, headache, galactorrhea, and irregular menstrual cycles. In affected individuals, prolactin levels are significantly elevated (>200 ng/mL). In contrast, this patient’s prolactin level is only mildly elevated, which is more suggestive of medication-induced hyperprolactinemia.  
❌ Primary breast malignancy:
Incorrect: A primary breast malignancy can present as a unilateral breast lump and bloody nipple discharge. In contrast, this patient has bilateral nipple discharge, elevated prolactin level, and a recent episode of psychosis. This history is more suggestive of hyperprolactinemia secondary to treatment with antipsychotic medication.  
❌ Polycystic ovarian syndrome:
Incorrect: Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is associated with hyperandrogenism and presents with a combination of hirsutism, topical treatment-resistant acne, menstrual irregularities, acanthosis nigricans, and obesity. It can occasionally cause elevated prolactin levels. This patient does not have typical signs of hyperandrogenism.  
✅ Medication side effect:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room by her neighbor after being found in an obtunded state with an empty bottle of medication next to her. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and major depressive disorder. Family history is noncontributory. Her temperature is 37.6 C (99.8 F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Serum chemistry and ECG findings are shown below. Which of the following medications most likely contributed to this patient’s presentation? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistry    
 Sodium      142 mEq/L    
 Potassium      4 mEq/L    
 Chloride      95 mEq/L    
 Creatinine      1.2 mg/dL    

Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient most likely attempted suicide by ingesting several pills of her antidepressant medication, most likely citalopram. This medication is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). It can cause dose-dependent QT interval prolongation, leading to life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias, such as torsade de pointes (polymorphic ventricular tachycardia). 

Clinicians should avoid prescribing high doses of citalopram (more than 40 mg per day) in susceptible patients (e.g., age >60, hepatic impairment, and concomitant medications that inhibit CYP2C19) and avoid it completely in patients with congenital long QT syndrome, bradycardia, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, recent myocardial infarction, or uncompensated heart failure. Moreover, a baseline ECG should be obtained before prescribing citalopram at doses greater than 40 mg per day or 20 mg per day in patients at risk for increased serum concentrations. Aside from citalopram and escitalopram, other SSRIs are unlikely to cause QT-prolongation.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.   

Option Analysis

❌ Lithium :
Incorrect: Lithium is a mood stabilizer prescribed for patients with bipolar disorder. Its side effect profile includes tremor, thyroid abnormalities (e.g. hypothyroidism), and polyuria (diabetes insipidus). It is not known to be directly cardiotoxic. 
❌ Phenelzine :
Incorrect: Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor used to treat atypical depression. It can cause a hypertensive crisis when consumed with tyramine-containing foods. QT-prolongation and ventricular arrhythmias are not typically associated with its use. 
✅ Citalopram :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Trazodone :
Incorrect: Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant used primarily for insomnia, as high doses are needed for antidepressant effects. Its toxicity can result in sedation, nausea, priapism, and postural hypotension. It has not been proven to be cardiotoxic. 
❌ Duloxetine :
Incorrect: Duloxetine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) used as a first-line antidepressant medication. Although venlafaxine (another SNRI) has been shown to increase the QT interval, no significant association has been found with duloxetine.
